The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include dividends and interest taxed as net capital gain, defined as net capital gain increased by qualified dividend income and qualified interest income. Qualified dividend income refers to dividends received from domestic corporations during the taxable year, excluding certain dividends. The term "dividend" excludes dividends from tax-exempt corporations, deductions under section 591, and dividends described in section 404(k). It also does not include dividends on shares held for a minimum period. The term "qualified interest income" includes interest on deposits with a bank and amounts paid on deposits by mutual savings banks, cooperative banks, and other financial institutions. The term "qualified interest income" includes interest on deposits with a bank, credit union, or savings institution insured under Federal or State law, as well as interest on corporate bonds and other evidences of indebtedness. The term "qualified interest income" includes interest on deposits with a bank, credit union, or savings institution insured under Federal or State law, as well as interest on corporate bonds and other evidences of indebtedness issued by domestic corporations, obligations of the United States, State, or political subdivision, and interest attributable to participation shares in a trust established by a corporation pursuant to Federal law. Special rules apply. Special rules apply to qualified dividend income and qualified interest income, excluding amounts considered as investment income under section 163(d)(4)(B). For nonresident alien individuals, these rules apply only for determining tax under section 871(b) and in respect of amounts effectively taxed. In the United States, tax is imposed on trade or business income and dividends from regulated investment companies and real estate investment trusts. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 addresses the treatment of dividends from regulated investment companies and real estate investment trusts. Qualified dividend income and interest income can be included as net investment income if the taxpayer elects to treat them as such. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to address the maximum rate of tax on dividends and interest received by regulated investment companies. If the sum of dividends and interest received is less than 95% of gross income, a specific computation applies. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to address the maximum rate of tax on dividends and interest received by regulated investment companies. In computing the maximum rate under section 1(h)(13), rules similar to those of subparagraph (A) apply. Gross income for this purpose includes the excess of net short-term capital gain over net long-term capital loss from sales or dispositions of stock or securities. Subparagraph (C) of section 854(b)(1) of the Code is also amended. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to address the maximum rate of tax on dividends and interest received by regulated investment companies. Subparagraph (C) of section 854(b)(1) is amended to include subparagraph (A) or (B). Section 857(c) is amended regarding restrictions on dividends from real estate investment trusts for tax purposes. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to address the treatment of dividends received from real estate investment trusts. If the interest received by the trust equals or exceeds 75 percent of its gross income, the dividend will be treated as interest for tax purposes. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 addresses the treatment of dividends from real estate investment trusts. If the interest received equals or exceeds 75 percent of gross income, the dividend will be treated as interest for tax purposes. Adjustments to gross income and aggregate interest received are made, excluding net capital gain and deductions allowable by section 163 for the taxable year. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 deals with dividends from real estate investment trusts. If interest received is 75% or more of gross income, the dividend is treated as interest for tax purposes. Gross income is adjusted by subtracting taxes imposed by specific sections, and aggregate interest received is calculated based on certain criteria. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2002. Trusts must notify shareholders of dividend amounts within 45 days after the end of the taxable year.
